expressions.meaning: To initiate a conversation in a social setting
expressions.example: He told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.

expressions.expression: Hit the nail on the head
expressions.meaning: To describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem
expressions.example: You hit the nail on the head when you said the problem was communication.
I'm feeling a bit under the weather today.

expressions.meaning: To endure a painful or difficult situation
expressions.example: I had to bite the bullet and apologize to him.

expressions.meaning_kr: 식은 죽 먹기, 아주 쉬운 일
expressions.example: The exam was a piece of cake.

expressions.expression: Cost an arm and a leg
expressions.example: That new car cost me an arm and a leg.

expressions.expression: Let the cat out of the bag
expressions.example: She let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.

expressions.expression: Kill two birds with one stone
expressions.meaning: To accomplish two things with a single action
expressions.example: By cycling to work, I kill two birds with one stone - saving money and staying fit.
He'll clean his room when pigs fly.
Come on, spill the beans! What happened?

expressions.meaning: To avoid talking about the main topic
expressions.example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you want.
We've done enough work. Let's call it a day.
The party got out of hand when more guests arrived.

expressions.meaning: To persist through a difficult time
expressions.example: Hang in there! Things will get better soon.
Come on, it's not rocket science. Just follow the instructions.
I missed the boat on that job opportunity.
Let's make sure we're all on the same page before we start.
I was just pulling your leg. I didn't mean it.

expressions.expression: Take it with a grain of salt
expressions.meaning: To not take something too seriously
expressions.example: Take his advice with a grain of salt.

expressions.expression: The ball is in your court
expressions.meaning: It's your turn to make a decision
expressions.example: I've done my part. The ball is in your court now.
We need to think outside the box to solve this problem.
Our vacation plans are still up in the air.

expressions.meaning: Something good that isn't recognized at first
expressions.example: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise.

expressions.meaning: To make a bad situation worse
expressions.example: His comments only added fuel to the fire.

expressions.meaning: To start over from the beginning
expressions.example: The project failed, so we're back to square one.

expressions.meaning: To pursue the wrong course of action
expressions.example: If you think I stole it, you're barking up the wrong tree.

expressions.meaning: It's better to do something late than not at all
expressions.meaning_kr: 안 하는 것보다 늦게라도 하는 게 낫다
expressions.example: You finally finished? Well, better late than never!

expressions.meaning: To work late into the night
expressions.example: I had to burn the midnight oil to finish the report.

expressions.meaning: To make peace and end a conflict
expressions.example: After years of fighting, they decided to bury the hatchet.

expressions.meaning: To do something in the easiest or cheapest way
expressions.example: Don't cut corners on safety measures.

expressions.meaning: Don't worry about things that have already happened
expressions.example: It's done now. Don't cry over spilled milk.

expressions.meaning: Something obtained easily is easily lost
expressions.example: He spent all his lottery winnings. Easy come, easy go.

expressions.meaning: To become nervous about doing something
expressions.example: He got cold feet before his wedding.
She always goes the extra mile for her customers.

expressions.meaning: To start something with immediate enthusiasm
expressions.example: We need to hit the ground running on this project.
He's in hot water with his boss.

expressions.meaning: To join a popular activity or trend
expressions.example: Everyone's jumping on the AI bandwagon.
Keep your chin up! You'll find a new job soon.
We'll leave no stone unturned to find the solution.
To make a long story short, we missed the train.

expressions.meaning: You have to work hard to achieve results
expressions.example: Keep exercising! No pain, no gain.
I only eat fast food once in a blue moon.
Let's just play it by ear and see what happens.

expressions.expression: Put all your eggs in one basket
expressions.meaning: To risk everything on a single opportunity
expressions.example: Don't put all your eggs in one basket. Diversify!
You need to read between the lines of her email.
We don't always see eye to eye on politics.
Stop sitting on the fence and make a decision.
It's a big decision. Why don't you sleep on it?

expressions.meaning: Said when someone appears just as they are mentioned
expressions.example: Speak of the devil! We were just talking about you.

expressions.meaning: To take credit for someone else's work
expressions.example: He stole my thunder by announcing my idea first.
Can I take a rain check on dinner tonight?
Working from home gives me the best of both worlds.

expressions.meaning: An obvious problem that no one wants to discuss
expressions.example: His drinking problem is the elephant in the room.

expressions.meaning: The final problem in a series
expressions.example: Being late again was the last straw.
After months of trying, she threw in the towel.
Time flies when you're having fun.
He turned a blind eye to the cheating.

expressions.expression: Two heads are better than one
expressions.example: Let's work together. Two heads are better than one.
I work well under pressure.

expressions.meaning: Past events that are no longer important
expressions.example: Our argument last year is water under the bridge.
I can't wrap my head around quantum physics.
"This weather is terrible." "You can say that again!"

expressions.meaning: What you do is more important than what you say
expressions.example: Don't just promise—actions speak louder than words.

expressions.expression: At the drop of a hat
expressions.example: She would help anyone at the drop of a hat.

expressions.expression: Bite off more than you can chew
expressions.meaning: To take on more than you can handle
expressions.example: I bit off more than I could chew with this project.

expressions.expression: By the skin of your teeth
expressions.example: I passed the exam by the skin of my teeth.

expressions.expression: Cross that bridge when you come to it
expressions.meaning: Deal with a problem when it arises
expressions.example: Don't worry about it now. Cross that bridge when you come to it.
Let's cut to the chase. What do you want?

expressions.expression: Don't judge a book by its cover
expressions.example: He looks tough, but don't judge a book by its cover.

expressions.expression: Every cloud has a silver lining
expressions.meaning: There's something good in every bad situation
expressions.example: I lost my job but found a better one. Every cloud has a silver lining.
You need to get your act together and focus.

expressions.expression: Give someone the benefit of the doubt
expressions.example: Let's give him the benefit of the doubt.
Don't stress. Just go with the flow.

expressions.expression: Have a lot on your plate
expressions.example: I can't take on more work. I have a lot on my plate.
I need to hit the books for my finals.
We're all in the same boat with this deadline.
Don't blame just her. It takes two to tango.
Don't jump the gun. Wait for the official announcement.
Can you keep an eye on my bag?
Don't bring up the past. Let sleeping dogs lie.
It's hard to make ends meet with rising prices.
Horror movies are not my cup of tea.

expressions.expression: Off the top of my head
expressions.example: Off the top of my head, I'd say about 50 people.
She called me out of the blue after 10 years.

expressions.meaning: To do your fair share of work
expressions.example: Everyone needs to pull their weight on this team.

expressions.meaning: To imagine being in someone's situation
expressions.example: Put yourself in her shoes before judging.
That name rings a bell, but I can't place it.
Don't rock the boat. Things are going well.

expressions.meaning: To save money for future needs
expressions.example: I always save some money for a rainy day.

expressions.meaning: To deal with only a small part
expressions.example: We've only scratched the surface of this topic.
I heard it straight from the horse's mouth.
Take it easy this weekend. You deserve a break.

expressions.meaning: A small part of a larger problem
expressions.example: These complaints are just the tip of the iceberg.
The answer was right under my nose all along.

expressions.meaning: To be very careful about what you say
expressions.example: I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around him.

expressions.expression: Wear your heart on your sleeve
expressions.example: She wears her heart on her sleeve.
First my car broke, then I got sick. When it rains, it pours.

expressions.expression: You can't have your cake and eat it too
expressions.meaning_kr: 두 마리 토끼를 잡을 수 없다
expressions.example: You want more free time but more money? You can't have your cake and eat it too.

expressions.expression: Your guess is as good as mine
expressions.example: When will this end? Your guess is as good as mine.
Let's zero in on the main issue.
